46.51.text:
The Liebherr LR 1600 is a heavy crawler
crane and has a maximum capacity of 600

51.88.text:
and you need to have a large capacity too
because it comes in a big box weighing

56.85.text:
It comes in a large outer shipping
container and the model box takes up the

61.29.text:
The box style is a standard Liebherr
design - there is a photo of the model on one

65.17.text:
and photos of the real crane on the other,
but there is no information about the

69.96.text:
The model is contained in three expanded
polystyrene trays which are factory sealed

74.46.text:
and as you can see there are a large
number of pieces in each of the three

78.77.text:
A feature of the packaging is the really
high-quality wrapping of all the parts.

83.07.text:
It's such a good job but it almost feels
a shame to unwrap it.

86.31.text:
Included with the model is a
comprehensive instruction manual that

90.75.text:
all the parts.   There is a reeving diagram for
the A-frame but it's not right so you

95.00.text:
can download an updated version from the
NZG web site,

98.31.text:
and there are plenty of a schematic
pictures.  It is quite a good manual but

104.34.text:
and a model like this could easily have
one twice the size.

115.12.text:
For the initial assembly we will just build
up the crane with a short main boom

118.61.text:
and the first task is to reeve up the
A-frame.   The luffing winches come

122.59.text: pre-wound with a single piece of thread and the first thing you have to do is to take it all off

125.60.text:
and that's because you need to reeve-up
the A-frame with just one continuous

129.51.text:
Once you've got it off it's best to
temporarily support the A-frame and that's done here

134.12.text:
an extra piece of thread.   The pulleys at
the back are also on a pivot so the best

138.21.text:
thing to do is to use 'ye olde'
elastic band.

141.50.text:
By using it in this high-tech manner you can
support the pulleys

145.88.text:
in a way that also gives it a bit of flex
which is also handy when you're reeving up.

149.47.text:
However reeving up is a long and
painstaking job - two hours worth at least -

153.52.text: and doing it this way both threads are being reeved simultaneously

157.33.text: starting in the middle and working outwards along the pulley bank.   Anyway three

161.43.text: seconds later the is job done......

163.36.text:
And the good news is that once it's done
you don't ever need to undo it because

167.10.text:
once it's reeved up you never to undo it
if you dismantle the model.

170.37.text:
Just like all the other winch drums this
one has a spring-loaded action with a

175.69.text:
and you wind it using a key.   On nice
touch is that the crane has hydraulic

180.13.text: rams which are used to push up the A-frame when it first arrives on site,

183.73.text:
and NZG has modelled it well with nice
telescopic mechanisms.

188.00.text:
At this point we will add our first bit of detail to
the crane which is some hand rails

192.16.text: These just slot in and they are a reasonably good fixing.

195.47.text:
Time to turn to some more weighty matters
so we will add some ballast trays

200.17.text:
and these attach on each side of the
crawler centre section.

203.28.text:
These are retained in place by nice little
L-bolts but it is not easy to do if you've got

208.49.text:
Luckily a much easier job is to add the
three counterweight ballast plates on

213.00.text:
and these are then followed by metal
walkways which hook into place.

216.80.text: These are all well-made metal parts that fit nicely.

219.94.text:
To allow the Cranes Etc team safe
access it's nice to provide some stairs

223.93.text: and they just slot into place,

225.55.text:
and then there's no excuse for not going
up top and adding some more ballast

229.61.text:
These ones just hang in place and there is a
protective handrail the clips in too,

233.96.text:
and that stops you falling in and getting mashed
up by the winches.

237.47.text:
Next we have a show with real skill where
both hands are being used at once to

245.77.text:
Let's now go for a bit more safety and
clip on a long handrail which goes on the

250.24.text: right hand side of the body,

251.79.text: and again it's a nicely fitting piece.

255.75.text:
These are the parts for a short main boom
configuration

258.61.text:
and the boom foot is a nice part with winch
number six being able to be set

262.31.text:
in an operating or transport position.   To
join the pieces up the connections are made

267.02.text:
in a high quality way using tiny brass
nuts-and-bolts,

270.73.text:
and special tools are provided with the
model to enable you to do that.

274.39.text:
Here the bolt has been installed in a
special holder

277.60.text:
and if you need to you can gently screw it
in through the paint

280.67.text:
thicknesses to get holes to line up.   Most
times though they just go straight through

285.51.text: and then you feed a nut

286.78.text:
into the special holder, pop it on to the
end of the bolt and then you can do it up

291.11.text:
and there's no need to do it too tightly.
Once it's done up it makes a good strong

296.65.text:
Repeat the process for the other bolts and here
is one I prepared earlier.

300.20.text:
it's a short main boom and it's also
got a short auxiliary lift head

304.09.text:
attached.   This is a nice part because
it's hinged

307.11.text:
so it doesn't take the whole weight of the
boom when it's horizontal.   With your stiff

311.40.text:
main boom in your hands you can now
push it into position.

314.35.text:
It slots in easy enough and you can use
a small screwdriver to line up the holes

319.35.text:
and then you can just feed in a silver
screw that holds it into position.

322.80.text:
There's also a nut that fits on the end
to hold it completely secure.

326.88.text:
The guys on this model are excellent and
realistic

330.37.text:
and they are connected with the same nut and bolt
system but using rather longer bolts.

334.60.text:
With the boom connected up the next job
is to reeve the hooks

337.82.text:
and for the main hook block definitely
the best thing to do is to suspend it

341.48.text: from the end of the boom.

342.70.text:
Here a short temporary chain is used to
hang it and it just makes reeving up

347.05.text:
much easier particularly as for this
block,  you need thread from two winch drums.

351.02.text:
With the basic assembly done it's time
to add some more detail

355.10.text:
and there are hand rails to put around
the winches on the boom.   The

358.32.text:
spring-loaded back stops that prevent the
boom from being raised vertical

361.90.text:
need to be positioned on the runners that are
just on the top edge of the crane body.

365.80.text:
The last bit of detail to add in this
configuration is some more walkways and

371.42.text:
an these all just press in down the left
hand side the model.

374.55.text:
Again they are metal parts that give the model
a nice realistic look

378.07.text:
and that completes this configuration of
the crane.

391.50.text:
The crawler center section is nicely
detailed with pipes but the hydraulic

396.76.text:
The metal crawler tracks are very finely
detailed and the track frames look really

401.43.text:
One very nice touch is that the mesh
walkways have lifting lugs.

405.03.text:
The cab has a very good interior and the external
detail is very good too.

409.18.text: At the boom foot slewing motors and hydraulic hoses are detailed,

413.28.text:
the winch drums look good and there are textured
walking surfaces on top.

416.90.text:
The counterweight blocks have graphics
and all of the pulleys are metal.

420.62.text:
The lattice sections are nicely made
complete with bracing at the ends

424.62.text:
and they are very straight and scaled well so
jib sections can fit inside boom sections

429.13.text:
for economic transport.   The mesh walkways
and handrails on the boom look great

433.69.text:
and they are matched by the high quality
metal guys.

436.85.text:
At the boom head the complex arrangement
is modelled really well

440.72.text:
and the metal hook blocks are of a high
standard too.

443.96.text:
The complex lattice work of the jib
struts is geometrically perfect and

448.90.text:
The ballast carrier is also excellently
engineered with high quality details.

463.63.text:
Starting with the crawler tracks they are
pinned to the centre section so if you

466.63.text:
remove those pins you can take the crawler
tracks off,

469.07.text:
and that means the model is great to
display as transport loads.

472.41.text:
All you need is some suitably large trucks
and a few blokes who look like they stand

476.69.text:
and then you've got a nice display.  The crawler
tracks themselves are nicely made parts

481.38.text:
they are quite stiff but you can turn them easily
enough by hand and they are spring-loaded at

485.41.text:
one end to keep the tension in the
tracks and stop them becoming unhooked.

488.60.text:
A particularly nice feature is that the
lifting points are provided

491.83.text:
so you can pose the track frames being
lifted properly.  With the tracks off

496.19.text: there are four hydraulic jacks that the can use too lift itself up,

499.77.text:
and NZG have made these to be
functional on the model.   The pads get

503.65.text:
secured to the ends of the pistons by
small plastic pins

506.86.text:
but in reality steel pins would have
been much better.   Once the pads are attached

510.63.text:
it is easy to lower the jacks by unscrewing
the pistons.

513.59.text:
To secure the pistons in a vertical
position there is another small pin that gets

517.92.text:
added.   With all four jacks set up you can
pose the model

521.43.text:
unloading its own crawler tracks.   All the
usual crane functions of the model

526.96.text:
Slewing the crane round is very
sure-footed and steady

530.35.text:
and the cab tilts well and can hold a pose.
The winches get operated by a key although a

536.60.text:
obstructed by either the counterweight or
the A-frame arms, and if you wanted you

540.52.text:
could use an electric screwdriver to
speed things up.

543.11.text:
One of the great features of the model
is that can build it in different ways

546.45.text:
and one of those configurations is just to
have a long straight boom using the

551.63.text:
This gives a simple but impressive model
and against the skyline you'd be

556.37.text:
hard-pressed to know that this wasn't
the real crane.

558.87.text:
But if you want to go for the max, all
the parts are in the box to have a derrick

562.77.text:
and here it is pre-assembled and also
a luffing jib and here it is made up ready.

567.93.text:
One of the jib struts is already
attached at the end

571.38.text:
and the other is a separate piece which
attaches to the boom head.

574.59.text:
On Cranes Etc we like our cranes
big so we'll go ahead and add the derrick.

578.92.text:
To make life easier the screws have been
partially tapped in at the ends before

583.77.text:
into the connection point.   Once it's in
place that is easier to tighten up using a

588.84.text:
The next job is to attach the guys to
the A-frame

592.44.text:
and to connect them using the past
nuts-and-bolts.   Once that's done you can

598.20.text:
and that begins to lift the derrick.   Next
the Cranes Etc detailing crew come

603.45.text:
and add some hand rails to the derrick.
The derrick increases the capacity of the

608.13.text:
crane by being attached to a ballast
carrier

610.37.text: and has been modelled really well by NZG. The big wheels all turn

615.81.text:
and there are a pair of large pull down
supports which are there to provide

619.02.text:
stability depending on how the wheels
are positioned.

621.56.text:
Both sets of wheels are mounted on their own
turntables

624.89.text:
so the ballast carrier can be attached to
the crane, and then towed along when it moves.

628.80.text:
Another nice little feature which has
been added is the access ladders which

634.15.text:
To connect the trailer to the crane there is an
extra piece

637.59.text:
and that attaches to the end of the
strut,  and then the whole thing is

642.73.text:
The strut is telescopic so it can be
fixed in different positions

646.28.text:
and the further away it is the more the crane
can lift.

650.47.text:
Here the strut is connected to the crane
and is also pinned using large screws

654.45.text: because the plastic pins supplied are too loose.

656.87.text:
There is one bit of detail to add which
is a hand rail which goes on the top

660.89.text:
and then the counterweight can be added.
The real crane can have a total counterweight

665.61.text:
load on the derrick of 350
tonnes

667.89.text:
so you can imagine that even at this
model size you get a very heavy trailer.

672.09.text:
The last thing to do is to connect the
guys from the top of the derrick

676.01.text:
down to the connection points on the
trailer.   When all that is done the derrick

680.89.text:
The whole thing works really well because
you can rotate the crane very smoothly

685.48.text:
Next the luffing jib has been attached and
reeved up which is another couple of hours

690.02.text:
and then we can add some final detail which
is some more walkways.

The luffing jib can now be raised to its
full height and for this it's best to use an

698.52.text:
With that done the model is now fully
assembled

704.87.text:
and what an impressive crane it is too
because all of the engineering is

709.02.text:
so the whole of the geometry is excellent.  It
also feels very strong so you can be

713.84.text:
confident that there wouldn't be any

716.85.text:
So when it is built big like this you certainly do
have a very impressive model

721.05.text:
but how big is it?   Let's get the tape
out and to the top it is nearly 78

727.72.text:
Another very nice touch is that NZG has

732.96.text:
This is really a first-class class
crane model from NZG

739.41.text:
and the finished profile for the crane is

742.48.text:
The detailing and functionality is very
good and what is great is the flexibility

746.60.text:
with which it can be configured in different

749.39.text: Without question it is an outstanding model.
